sols_html:
We first compute the derivative of \(y = 1 + (2/3)x^{3/2}\) and see that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dx} = \sqrt{x}\end{aligned}\]

Plugging this into the arc length formula gives

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1}\sqrt{1 + \left(\frac{dy}{dx} \right)^{2}} \, dx = \int_{0}^{1} \sqrt{1 + \sqrt{x}^{2}}\,dx = \int_{0}^{1}\sqrt{1 + x}\, dx\end{aligned}\]

Now, let \(u = 1+x\) so that \(du = dx\) and \(u(0) = 1\) and \(u(1) = 2\). Then

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{1}\sqrt{1 + x}\, dx &= \int_{1}^{2}\sqrt{u}\, du \\ &= \left.\frac{2u^{3/2}}{3}\right|_{1}^{2} \\ &= \frac{2}{3} \left(2^{3/2} - 1 \right) \\ &= \frac{2}{3} \left(2\sqrt{2}-1 \right)\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
